alert.note: Alert for Greenwood; Newberry; Saluda (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 5:19PM EST until January 11 at 9:27PM EST by NWS Columbia
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Columbia SC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in South Carolina... Saluda River At Chappells affecting Newberry, Greenwood and Saluda Counties. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO LATE THURSDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast due to heavy rainfall across the Upstate and Piedmont of South Carolina over the past 12 hours. * WHERE...Saluda River at Chappells. * WHEN...From this evening to late Thursday evening. * IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Lowlands around and downstream from Chappells become flooded. Cattle grazing river bottomland should be moved to higher ground. At 16.0 feet, Extensive farmland and river bottomland around and downstream from Chappells become flooded. At 18.0 feet, The Saluda River Campground including the Campground Store downstream from Chappells becomes flooded. Campers should move to higher ground. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:15 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 9.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage late this evening to 17.5 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow evening to 8.2 feet Friday morning. It will rise to 8.3 feet early Friday afternoon. It will then fall to 8.2 feet early Saturday morning. It will rise to 8.3 feet Saturday evening. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Most flooding deaths occur in vehicles. Never drive through a flooded roadway or around barricades. Turn around, don`t drown. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Residents and those with interests near the river should monitor rising water levels and take action if necessary. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 530 AM EST.
